Caption: Fig. 1. An illustration of exploration enabled in our proposed Dimension Projection Tree/Matrix visualization of high dimensional data. Each node is consist of one data item plot and one dimension plot. Starting from an initial node (1), users can explore either in data item space (2, 3) or dimension space (4, 5, 6), by first selecting a subset of data items or dimensions, and then creating child nodes (3, 4, 5) or converting one single dimension project plot into a matrix representation (6).
Fig. 2. Illustration of clustering in subspaces. Separation of clusters in appropriate selection of dimension subspaces can be much easier than that in the original high dimensional space.

Fig. 3. Illustration of a Dimension Projection Matrix node. Each node represents a portion of the high-dimensional dataset defined by a set of dimensions and a set of data items. The data item plot is shown as an Dimension Projection Matrix of dimension groups. The upper right cells of the matrix show Dimension Projection of data items on the cor- responding dimensions, while the lower left cells of the matrix show Di- mension Projection of the corresponding dimensions. The dimensions for each cell are indicated by the dimension indicators. The dimension plot is an Dimension Projection of all dimensions in the node.
Fig. 5. Subspace exploration via splitting and merging dimension groups. Dimensions A to E in the left node are split into 3 groups (cen- ter), and then two groups are merged (right).
Fig. 5. Subspace exploration via splitting and merging dimension groups. Dimensions A to E in the left node are split into 3 groups (cen- ter), and then two groups are merged (right).
Fig. 8. Child nodes with subset of data items. A region surrounding the selected data items is drawn behind the plots, indicating the data item selection of each child node.

Fig. 6. Focus+Context zoom on plot size. Left: default plot sizes; Cen- ter: the second dimension group is zoomed in; Right: the first group is zoomed in.
Fig. 9. Experiments on the USDA food composition dataset. See section 5.1 for details about the exploration process.

Fig. 10. Experiments on the CADASTER dataset. (a) shows the plot of the original dataset and the two classes. The tree is constructed in an order of (a), (c), (d), (e), (f), (g), (h) and (i). See section 5.2 for details about the exploration process.
